name: GJ 3998
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 3998 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 3998 is a star with 0.5 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.49 times its radius. It is located 59.23 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 3998 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 3998 system


GJ 3998 b

GJ 3998 b was discovered by the Roque de los Muchachos Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 3998 b is 2.47086 times the mass of Earth. At 2.47086 Earth masses, GJ 3998 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 3998 c

GJ 3998 c was discovered by the Roque de los Muchachos Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 3998 c is 6.2646 times the mass of Earth. At 6.2646 Earth masses, GJ 3998 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 3998, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Roque de los Muchachos Observatory.
